title: Erdős Problem #495: The Littlewood Conjecture
description: Let α, β ∈ ℝ. Is lim inf n·‖nα‖·‖nβ‖ = 0? The famous Littlewood conjecture. EKL (2006): counterexamples have Hausdorff dimension zero. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #495 is the Littlewood conjecture (c. 1930), one of the most famous open problems in Diophantine approximation. It asks whether every pair of reals can be simultaneously well-approximated by rationals in a multiplicative sense. Einsiedler–Katok–Lindenstrauss (2006) proved the set of counterexamples has Hausdorff dimension zero, earning Lindenstrauss the 2010 Fields Medal.
overview.problemStatement: Let α, β ∈ ℝ. Is it true that lim inf (n → ∞) n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖ = 0, where ‖x‖ is the distance to the nearest integer?
overview.proofStrategy: We define the distance-to-nearest-integer function distInt, the Littlewood product, and state the conjecture as an infinitely-often condition. Special cases (rational, cubic irrationals via Cassels–Swinnerton-Dyer) and the EKL dimension-zero theorem are axiomatized.
keyInsights: The Littlewood conjecture asks for multiplicative simultaneous approximation
Trivially true when α or β is rational (the product vanishes at multiples of the denominator)
Einsiedler–Katok–Lindenstrauss (2006): counterexamples have Hausdorff dimension zero
The p-adic variant (de Mathan–Teulié) is also open

sections.title: Part I: Distance to Nearest Integer
sections.summary: Defines distInt (distance to nearest integer) and its basic properties.

sections.title: Part II: The Littlewood Product
sections.summary: Defines the Littlewood product L(n, α, β) = n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖.

sections.title: Part III: The Littlewood Conjecture
sections.summary: States the Littlewood conjecture: lim inf of the product is zero for all α, β.

sections.title: Part IV: Special Cases
sections.summary: Rational case and Cassels–Swinnerton-Dyer (1955) for cubic irrationals.

sections.title: Part V: The EKL Theorem
sections.summary: Einsiedler–Katok–Lindenstrauss (2006): counterexamples have Hausdorff dimension zero.

sections.title: Part VI: The p-adic Littlewood Conjecture
sections.summary: The p-adic variant of de Mathan–Teulié (2004) and Badziahin–Velani (2014).

sections.title: Part VII: Summary
sections.summary: Status: open in full generality. Known for rationals, cubics, and almost all pairs.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #495 is the Littlewood conjecture: for all α, β ∈ ℝ, lim inf n·‖nα‖·‖nβ‖ = 0. Known for rationals, cubic irrationals (Cassels–Swinnerton-Dyer 1955), and almost all pairs (EKL 2006, Hausdorff dimension zero). Still open in full generality.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would have profound consequences for simultaneous Diophantine approximation, ergodic theory on homogeneous spaces, and our understanding of the interplay between additive and multiplicative number theory.
openQuestions: Does there exist any explicit pair (α, β) of algebraically independent reals for which the conjecture can be verified?
Can the EKL measure-zero result be strengthened to prove the full conjecture?
Is the p-adic Littlewood conjecture true for all primes p and all reals α?
